phrases: Patient was called for a follow-up with me for chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction.
BMP's been 3,000 in March, and is about six- was up to 6,000 in April.
We changed her furosemide and torsemide 20 milligrams by mouth daily.
The patient is not currently on potassium supplement.
Her lisinopril had also been increased up to 10 milligrams daily in March.
She reported being interested in having her knee replaced this summer at East Metro. It was recommended that we work to control her cardiovascular status before surgery.
I see you're scheduled on the 24th for surgery.
We want to keep a close eye on you to make sure a week before your surgery you donâ€™t suddenly go into congestive heart failure and it gets postponed.
You have lost about 3, 3 and a half pounds since I saw you last in April.
I had leg cramps the other day, but I thought it might was maybe just because I was cold as I had my ceiling fan on and fell asleep.
I drank pickle juice and it went away. I find it works a lot better than trying to put some cream on my leg.
No, it did get bad for a while I tried to take some Prilosec and stopped that other one. After I stopped taking that I went back to the stomach one, I'm doing good.
Your magnesium level because sometimes you urinate out magnesium with the water pills but it was normal at 1.7.
Your potassium is 3.9 it's holding steady on the torsemide. Your creatinine was 0.7 not 0.8 you're doing with kidney numbers. Your BUN may be a tiny bit elevated at 23.
Your blood sugar is a little bit high, it was 169 today but that depends on what you ate and you weren't fasting for the blood check.
Your hemoglobin level because you have had some anemia in the past but that is still doing great.
We often to keep people with heart problems on magnesium and get their levels up to around the 2-ish range. I might recommend putting you on magnesium supplement.
Before surgery we'll have to get you off your clopidogrel for a week beforehand.
We will also need to complete a pre-op check within two weeks of your surgery during the first or second week of June.

We do not need to any x-rays of your chest because you had one recently, and we do not need any more blood work because we did that today. We might also have to repeat an EKG before surgery which we could do today.
Lastly, once we get your knee surgery, we should think about getting you a colonoscopy. We can do it here locally because you have Medicare.
My husband's insurance may be running out. Might we be able to get the procedure done sooner?
I can put it in for County for the next 30 days, and they might be able to get you in within the next few weeks.
Your last A1c was 5.5 in March. Your blood sugar is a little bit high, it was 169 today... I do not think we need to do it today.
